item.title: Linear Algebra: Vector Spaces
item.description: We will discuss the vector space initially as an abstract notion before diving into examples and then some further explanations. \(Let\ V\ be\ a\ non-empty\ set.\ Let\ \boldsymbol{a, b,c }\ \in\ V\ and\ \lambda\ , \mu\ \in\ \mathbb{R}.\) We will denote \(\oplus\) as ‘sum’ and \(\circ\) as ‘scalar multiplication’. V now satisfies the following axioms: \[\begin{align} &(i)\ \ \ \ a\oplus b \in V \ \ &[the\ sum\ of\ \boldsymbol{a}\ and\ \boldsymbol{b}\ is\ in\ V] \\\\ &(ii)\ \ \ \ (a\oplus b)\oplus c= a\oplus (b\oplus c)\ &[the\ \boldsymbol{associativity\ law}\ holds\ for\ \ \oplus] \\\\ &(iii)\ \ \ \ \exists\ e\ \in\ V\ \mid\ a\oplus e = e\oplus a = a\ &[Existence\ of\ the\ \boldsymbol{identity\ element}] \\\\ &(iv)\ \ \ \ \forall\ a\ \in\ V\ there\ exists\ b\ \in\ V\ \mid\ a\oplus b = b\oplus a = e\ &[Existence\ of\ the\ \boldsymbol{right\ \&\ left\ Inverse}]\\\\ &(v)\ \ \ \ a\oplus b = b\oplus a\ &[the\ \boldsymbol{commutativity\ law}\ holds\ for\ \ \oplus]\\\\ &(vi)\ \ \ \ \lambda \circ a\ \in\ V\ &[scalar\ multiples\ \in\ V]\\\\ &(vii)\ \ \ \ \lambda \circ (a\oplus b)=\lambda \circ a\oplus \lambda \circ b &[1^{st}\ \boldsymbol{distributivity\ law}\ holds]\\\\ &(viii)\ \ \ \ \lambda + \mu \circ a = \lambda \circ a\oplus \mu \circ a &[2^{nd}\ \boldsymbol{distributivity\ law}\ holds]\\\\ &(ix)\ \ \ \ \lambda \circ (\mu \circ a) = (\lambda\mu)\circ a &[the\ \boldsymbol{associativity\ law}\ holds\ for\ \ \circ]\\\\ &(x)\ \ \ \ 1 \circ a = a &[Existence\ of\ the\ \boldsymbol{identity\ element}\ for\ \ \circ]\\\\ \end{align}\]
